lines.text: One day men will look back and say that I gave birth to the twentieth century.
You're not going to see the twentieth century.
[reading the return address on the package sent by Jack the Ripper]
"From Hell". Well at least they got the address right.

Below the skin of history are London's veins. These symbols, the mitre, the pentacle star, even someone as ignorant and degenerate as you can sense that they course with energy and meaning. I am that meaning. I am that energy.
Why have you called me here, Netley.

It's just... you say only three more have to be killed. I don't know if I can do it anymore. It's in all the papers. I'm just a simple chap, sir. I'm not a great man like you. I just don't know where I am anymore.
There, there Netley. I shall tell you where we are. We're in the darkest region of the human brain, a radiant abyss where men go to find themselves.
I don't understand, sir.
Hell, Netley. We are in hell.
What's wrong? You think I was born a whore? Oh that's right, England doesn't have whores, just a great mass of very unlucky women.
[after trying to kiss Abberline and he refuses]
What? You think I was paying you back? I didn't mean it as business. I'm still a woman, they haven't taken that away from me, not yet anyways!
[Abberline proceeds to shove her against the wall and kiss her passionately]
You stand before your peers, masons and doctors both.
I have no peers present here.
What?

No man amongst you is fit to judge... the mighty art that I have wrought. Your rituals are empty oaths you neither understand nor live by. The Great Architect speaks to me. He is the balance where my deeds are weighed and judged... not you.
It's over with, It's done. You have my word.
Fuck your word! I will bring down every one of you fucking cunts!
This ain't killin' for profit. This is ritual.
[Johnny Depp's first lines]
[Sergeant Godley slaps Abberline to wake him up]
Hello, darling.

[about Polly's murder]
I'm waiting for the police surgeon's report for more details.

[sits at his desk while smoking a cigarette]
I see. Well, one thing's for certain; an Englishman didn't do it.
[Warren pulls up a newspaper clipping of American Natives]
Maybe one of these Red Indians wandered into Whitechapel and indulged his natural inclinations.
[Abberline looks doubtfully at the drawing]
With all due respect, sir, I believe this was done by someone with at least a working knowledge of dissection. An educated man, such as a doctor...

[quickly interjects]
An educated man? That's preposterous! No well-bred man would do this!
[pause]
Probably a tradesman or a butcher...

[nods]
A tradesman is a possibility, sir, yes...
[pause]
But there's a strong indication against it. There was a sprig of grapes under her body.
What are you driving at?
No one in Whitechapel, no matter what their trade, could afford grapes. Obviously, they were given to her by the killer. It follows that he must be someone with money.
Laudanum is a derivative of opium. Apart from doctors and addicts, not many would be able to detect it. How long have you been chasing the dragon, Inspector?
Why?
Are you questioning my decision?
No, sir, I just simply want to know why.
I want every veterinarian, butcher, furrier in the district interviewed.
Furrier? What he do, sir? Skin her?
He disemboweled her. Removed her stomach, intestines...

[to her John]
All right. We can do it here, but hurry up.
[they start to undress]
The bobbies are trackin' us!
Right.
[he pulls down his pants]
Gotta get the old man hard first.
Give it here. I'll put it in meself!
[she grabs his genitals]
Is that in?
Of course it is. Come on!
No, it's not. Ya got it stuck between yer bleedin' legs!

[frustratingly]
No, I haven't! Come on!
I knows it when I feels it!
[they start copulating against the wooden fence]
Right, once more into the breach, gentlemen!
[the police constables remain where they are, confused]
Dismissed.
They used to burn men like you, alive.
There's your typical Londoner, imbued with Christian sympathy for his fellow man, or fellow whore in this case.
You do not fuck with the special branch, the special branch fucks with you.

Dr Ferral]
He knows all about Anatomy and nothing about the soul.
You could be dead... right now. But then there would be too many bloody questions.
How did he find out about the unfortunate and her child?
Well, he has that kind of cleverness you'll sometimes find in the middle classes. A cheap sort of intelligence, but effective nevertheless.
Hmm. Thank God that's not something you're burdened by.
Yes, thank God.
[last lines]
Goodnight, sweet prince.
Sorry about the rude awakening.
A rose by any other name?
Have you forgotten the most telling fact? What ever the Prince may be, he knows little or nothing about human anatomy.
I pay. I already pay.
I'm not after you, emperor. Where is he?
We work the streets harder than ever, right?
We were starving. But we were starving in fresh air.
I think you mean to draw a Lister knife.
Withers, when the inspector is talking you are listening.
Withers, when the inspector is talking you are what?
Listening, sir.
And Withers, for your information... the star of David has six points.
My God. He's out of his mind.
That's very astute of you sir.

[in Jack the Ripper's carriage]
That was the thing that was in my dream. What's it called again?
Cleopatra's Needle.
Cleopatra, she was a beauty.
They were carved 1450 years before the son of God was born. Six men died bringing it here.
[kills Polly]
Boo! Did I scare ya? I've been looking for you. I've been looking all over you.
You've been looking for me?
Not for me. For my gentleman. Very fine gentleman. He sent me to look for you.
Your gentleman sent you to look for me? Oh, get off! I may be an unfortunate, but I'm not a blithering idiot!
It's the truth! It's the God's truth! He's seen ya, he likes ya, and he said tonight only you'll do.
Look, I bring everything for supper!

[snatches an envelope full of money]
You little thief! I need this money!
I only take some money to buy food. For me and for you. Was that bad, Marie?
It's fine, dear. But until I go away, it's not safe for you to go out by yourself.

[caresses Mary's face]
I stay with Marie, beautiful Marie.
It's alright, darling. You don't have to pay for your food.
Pardon?

[approaching his carriage carefully]
'ello, sir.
Is anything wrong?
No sir. For a second, I thought you were someone else.
Oh.
[offers her absinthe spiked with laudanum]
Thirsty?

[takes it and drinks]
Always parched, sir.

[Arrives in pub with Ada]
Ah 'ere you are, 'ello girls.
I told you to wait for me.
that's cruel.
Sergeant? It's night.
Your observations are correct. It is indeed night.
[turns to two constables]
And gentlemen, unless you wish to be free of the confines of your duties, this never happened.
You know who you're going to turn into. That sad old man in the pub that no-one wants to sit beside because after a few drinks he'll start talking about the girl that got away.

[as they make love]
I have wonderful news.
Tell me.
Surely you, of all people, can guess.
I don't want to guess with you.
Dr.Marbury says...
Dr.Marbury says?
Dr.Marbury says I'm going to have your child.
[Abberline smiles and kisses Victoria]
